content: The Act titled "Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016" extends termination dates for SBIR and STTR programs from 2017 to 2022. Administrative funding deadlines are also extended to 2022. Required expenditure amounts are specified in the Act. The Small Business Act is amended to specify required expenditure amounts for SBIR funding in fiscal years 2018, 2019, and 2020. The Small Business Act is amended to specify required expenditure amounts for SBIR funding in fiscal years 2028 and beyond, increasing annually from 3.46% in 2018 to 4.50% in 2022 and subsequent years. The Small Business Act is amended to increase required expenditure amounts for SBIR funding annually, reaching 4.50% in fiscal year 2022 and beyond. The Small Business Act is amended to increase required expenditure amounts for SBIR funding annually, reaching 4.50% in fiscal year 2022 and beyond. Amendments include incremental increases from 0.50% in 2018 to 0.60% in 2022 and beyond. SEC. 4. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to require reports to be submitted by December 31 and March 30 of each year. The Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 638) is amended to require reports to be submitted not later than March 30 of each year, with specific details outlined for the content of the reports. The Small Business Act is amended to require agencies to submit a simplified and standardized report to the Small Business Administration by March 30 of each year. The Small Business Act is amended to require each agency to submit a simplified and standardized report to the Small Business Administration by March 30 of each year. The Small Business Act is amended to require each agency to submit a report to the Small Business Administration by March 30 of each year, detailing instances of compliance. The Small Business Act is amended to require agencies to submit compliance reports by specific deadlines each year. The Small Business Act is amended to require agencies to submit compliance reports by specific deadlines each year, including March 30 and June 30 for certain subsections. The Small Business Act is amended to require agencies to report administrative funds by March 30 each year. The Small Business Act now mandates that Federal agencies report their use of administrative funds by March 30 each year. Federal agencies must report their use of administrative funds to the Administrator if authorized, failure to do so will result in the agency not being eligible for fund use unless the report is submitted along with an additional report. Federal agencies failing to submit required reports will not be eligible for fund use unless the report is submitted along with an additional report outlining plans for timely reporting. SEC. 5. INDEXING AWARDS FOR INFLATION. Section 9 of the Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 638) is amended to reorganize and modify certain subsections and clauses. Section 9 of the Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 638) is amended by reorganizing and modifying certain subsections and clauses, including changes to subparagraphs, clauses, and the addition of a new subsection for awards under Phase I and Phase II adjusted for inflation. The Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 638) is amended to include new subsections for awards under Phase I and Phase II adjusted for inflation. Phase I awards are capped at $150,000, and Phase II awards at $1,000,000, with adjustments for inflation by the Administrator. The Small Business Act is amended to set limits on Phase I and Phase II awards under SBIR or STTR programs. Phase I awards are capped at $150,000, while Phase II awards are capped at $1,000,000, with adjustments for inflation by the Administrator. SEC. 6 amends the Small Business Act to change the wording regarding insertion incentives. SEC. 7 clarifies the eligibility of certain small businesses. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify the eligibility of certain small businesses for receiving awards under the SBIR and STTR programs. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify that certain small business concerns are eligible to receive awards under the SBIR and STTR programs. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify eligibility of certain small businesses to receive awards under the STTR program. SEC. 8. COMMERCIALIZATION ASSISTANCE PILOT PROGRAM. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program for eligible entities to receive a second sequential SBIR award within one year of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The Small Business Act is amended to include a Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program for eligible entities to receive a second sequential SBIR award within one year of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. If a covered agency has a similar program, they are exempt from implementing the pilot program. The Small Business Act is amended to include a Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program for eligible entities to receive a second sequential SBIR award within one year of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. Covered agencies with similar programs are exempt from implementing the pilot program, and agency funds for awards under the program are limited to 5 percent of the total SBIR budget. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program limits agency funds to 5% of the total SBIR budget and will terminate on September 30, 2022. The Administrator will require a matching requirement for awards under the program. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program will end on September 30, 2022. The Administrator will mandate a matching requirement for awards under the program. Under a commercialization assistance pilot program, a matching amount equal to the award must be provided by an eligible third-party investor before the program ends. Ineligible funding sources cannot be used to meet the matching requirement. The size of the award will be determined under this program. Under the commercialization assistance pilot program, awards must not exceed specified limitations and will be distributed during the Phase II award period. Funding from ineligible sources cannot be used to meet the matching requirement. The commercialization assistance pilot program awards will be distributed during the Phase II award period. To receive a second sequential SBIR award, eligible entities must submit an application to the implementing agency. To receive a second sequential SBIR award under a commercialization assistance pilot program, eligible entities must submit an application to the implementing agency containing required information and matching funding details. The awarded funds can only be used for research and development activities that build on the eligible entity's work. The commercialization assistance pilot program requires applicants to provide matching funding details and specifies that awarded funds can only be used for research and development activities that advance towards commercialization. Recipients are selected based on various criteria determined by the head of the agency. The commercialization assistance pilot program aims to accelerate entities towards commercialization by awarding supplemental funds based on the potential for research commercialization and technical feasibility. Recipients are selected based on specific criteria set by the agency head. The pilot program awards supplemental funds based on potential for research commercialization and technical feasibility. Criteria for selection include the extent of aid for commercialization, sound approach for technical feasibility, improvements to the commercialization plan, and societal benefits. The Phase II commercialization plan should reflect changes that improve the chances of research conversion for societal benefits. Progress in Phase II activities must justify additional funding, considering third-party funding expectations and the likelihood of commercial and societal benefits. The Phase II commercialization plan must show progress to justify additional funding, considering third-party funding expectations and the potential for commercial and societal benefits. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit an evaluation report on commercialization assistance pilot programs within 3 years of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The report will include a summary of activities and results achieved. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit an evaluative report to the Representatives and the Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship of the Senate. The report will summarize the activities and results of commercialization assistance pilot programs, including the number of small businesses awarded, commercialization rates, and growth in employment and revenue. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit an evaluative report to the Representatives and the Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship of the Senate summarizing the commercialization assistance pilot programs. This report will include details on the number of small business concerns that received awards, commercialization rates, growth in employment and revenue of participating companies, comparison of success with non-matching Phase II recipients, and demographic information such as ethnicity. The evaluative report on the commercialization assistance pilot programs will include details on the growth in employment and revenue of participating companies, comparison of success with non-matching Phase II recipients, demographic information such as ethnicity and geographic location, an accounting of funds used at each participating agency, and distribution of third-party funding by source. The evaluative report on the commercialization assistance pilot programs will include demographic information, funds used at each agency, third-party funding distribution, program effectiveness analysis, and recommendations for improvement if made permanent. The evaluative report on the commercialization assistance pilot programs will include an analysis of effectiveness at each participating agency, recommendations for improvement if made permanent, and definitions for covered agency and eligible entity. The term 'covered agency' refers to a Federal agency with an SBIR program, while 'eligible entity' is a small business that has received Phase II awards. 'Eligible third-party investors' are small businesses or ventures other than the eligible entity. Phase II award and a Phase II sequential award from the covered agency to which such entity is applying for a second sequential SBIR award. Eligible third-party investors include small business concerns, venture capital firms, individual investors, non-SBIR Federal, State, or local governments. Ineligible sources refer to the awardee's internal research. Ineligible sources for funding under the SBIR program include the awardee's internal research and development funds, funding in forms other than cash, and funding from the owners of the eligible entity or their family members. Ineligible sources for funding under the SBIR program include internal research and development funds, funding in forms other than cash, funding from owners of the eligible entity or their family members, and funding attained through loans or debt obligations. SEC. 9. INCREASED UNDERSERVED POPULATION PARTICIPATION WAIVER REMOVED. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to include provisions for outreach, technical assistance, and increasing the participation of states with historically low SBIR awards. Conforming amendments are also made to ensure consistency. The Small Business Act is amended to increase state participation in SBIR awards, with a conforming amendment made to ensure consistency.
